title: France in the Eurovision Song Contest 1981
text:
France was present at the Eurovision Song Contest 1981, held in <a href="Dublin">Dublin</a>, <a href="Republic%20of%20Ireland">Ireland</a>.
Before Eurovision.
"Concours de la Chanson Française pour l'Eurovision 1981".
The final was held on 8 March 1981 at the <a href="TF1">TF1</a> Studios in <a href="Paris">Paris</a>, and was hosted by television hostess <a href="Fabienne%20%C3%89gal">Fabienne Égal</a>. Six songs made it to the national final after two semi-final heats. The winner was decided by a random sampling of 1,086 television viewers who were contacted by TF1 and asked which song was their favorite.
The winning entry was "<a href="Humanahum">Humanahum</a>," performed by Jean Gabilou and composed by <a href="Jean-Paul%20Cara">Jean-Paul Cara</a> with lyrics by Joe Gracy. Cara and Gracy also penned the 1977 Contest winner "<a href="L%27oiseau%20et%20l%27enfant">L'oiseau et l'enfant</a>". Gabilou, a Tahitian singer, was the first ever to represent France from one of its <a href="Overseas%20departments%20and%20territories%20of%20France">overseas territories</a>.
The order of the songs presented on the night of the Contest vary from other published material.
At Eurovision.
Jean Gabilou performed ninth on the night of the contest, following <a href="Finland">Finland</a> and preceding <a href="Spain">Spain</a>. At the close of the voting the song had received 125 points, placing 3rd in a field of 20 competing countries. Despite finishing in the top three, TF1's head of entertainment programming, Pierre Bouteiller, famously opted out of the <a href="Eurovision%20Song%20Contest%201982">1982 Contest</a>, referring to Eurovision as "a monument to inanity [sometimes translated as "drivel"]." France would return to the fold in <a href="Eurovision%20Song%20Contest%201983">1983</a>.
